title-group.article-title: Do Charitable Solicitations Matter? A Comparative Analysis of Fundraising Methods

abstract.p: The existing literature either treats fundraising as an aggregate variable by ignoring the existence of several different fundraising methods through which charitable contributions are generated or focuses on the effectiveness of a particular fundraising method without making any comparison with alternative methods. Using biennial household surveys of charitable giving in the United States conducted from 1988 to 1999, which contain detailed questions on several fundraising methods, I first document that people are more responsive to certain fundraising methods. Next, I investigate the factors associated with donors' responsiveness to alternative fundraising techniques. The results show that several observable characteristics of charitable donors are associated with some people being more responsive to particular fundraising techniques than others are.

For this particular survey year, I estimate total giving as the sum of money that the respondent has reported contributing to each of the specific charity groups that they were asked about, excluding donations to political organisations. 1 also exclude informal and work-related contributions, and contributions to friends, neighbours, relatives and strangers.

These figures are comparable to those in other sources of data on charitable donations in the US such as the Panel Study of Income Dynamics. Table Al in the online appendix presents the summary statistics and definitions of key variables used in the empirical analysis (see http://www.ifs.org.uk/docs/fsdecl2 voruk appendix.pdf).

Donors were asked the following question: 'How was it you came to give to [name of the charitable category]? Would you say that you decided to give on your own, responded to being asked by someone, to a letter, (to a phone call), to an advertisement in the media, or to some other fundraising method?' (donors were given the option to reply 'responded to a phone call' only in the 1990 edition). In both 1988 and 1990 editions, some respondents picked multiple choices and some others either did not answer this question or said that they did not remember the catalyst for their donation. Since it is impossible to make comparisons across donors who reported donating as a response to multiple fundraising methods, I only consider those donors who reported giving as a response to a single fundraising method. As a result, I deleted 1,251 observations.
This estimate may be misleading due to the low sample size of those who reported giving solely as a response to a telephone solicitation.

The survey does not provide any information about the proportion of people who are approached to give by different fundraising methods. If the proportion of people who are approached to give by a certain fundraising method is significantly larger or smaller than the proportion who are approached to give by other fundraising methods, then survey responses will reflect this fact. Therefore sample statistics should be interpreted with caution. I acknowledge an anonymous referee for pointing out this caveat.

The wording of this question was as follows: 'How important is each of the following reasons to you for contributing to a charitable organization? Receiving a letter asking you to give, receiving a phone call asking you to give, someone coming to the door asking you to give, being asked at work to give, being asked by someone you know well to give, seeing a television commercial asking you to give, reading a newspaper or magazine advertisement asking you to give, reading or hearing a news story, being asked to give in a telethon or radiothon, being asked by clergy to give, being asked by a celebrity to give either on television, radio, or through the mail, reading about an opportunity or being solicited over the internet, [and having] volunteered at the organization before. ' This question was not asked in the 1990 edition of the survey. The 1988 edition included a similar question, but the wording of the question and the coding of the responses were considerably different from in the other editions, so I exclude the responses from this year.
Although professional fundraisers are well aware of this result, most charities keep using direct-mail and telephone solicitations, TV ads, and newspaper or magazine ads (Hopkins, 2009).

Since the empirical analysis is based on self-reported survey data, the results may be prone to measurement error and self-reporting bias. If self-reporting bias is correlated with the amount of charitable contribution and the responsiveness to a certain fundraising method, then the empirical analysis does not yield consistent estimates of the impact of alternative fundraising methods on the amount of charitable contributions. Similarly, the empirical analysis is based on pooled cross-sectional data due to the unavailability of panel data on alternative fundraising methods. Therefore, one cannot control for individual fixed effects that may affect giving behaviour. If individual fixed effects or other unobserved variables that may affect charitable behaviour are also correlated with respondents' responsiveness to certain fundraising methods, then one cannot estimate the impact of alternative fundraising methods on charitable giving using a simple regression model that assumes the exogeneity of fundraising methods.

Following the standard practice in the literature, 1 use the natural logarithm transformations of household income and the tax price of giving. The selection of control variables is based on the earlier literature that investigates the determinants of charitable giving. Andreoni (2006) provides a detailed discussion of this literature. A potential problem in equation (1) is the endogeneity of the tax price of giving. A widely-used instrument for the last-dollar price of giving in the literature is the first-dollar price, which excludes the charitable contributions. Since the main variable of interest is not the tax price, instrumenting this variable with the first-dollar price or, alternatively, excluding it from the empirical analysis has a very minor impact on the estimated effects of fundraising methods on charitable behaviour. For instance, when I exclude the tax price from the regression and re-estimate equation (1), I find the coefficients and standard errors on alternative fundraising methods to be as follows: asked by someone = -0.409 (0.170); direct- mail solicitation = -0.566 (0.356); media ad = -1.015 (0.276); and other fundraising method = -0.353 (0.096). These estimates are quite similar to the results reported in the first column of Table A2. Furthermore, tests find that the differences between the alternative estimates are statistically insignificant. I also instrument the last-dollar price with the first-dollar price and re-estimate equation (1). Again, the coefficients on alternative fundraising methods remain quite similar to those reported in Table A2. This analysis suggests that potential problems due to the possible endogeneity of the tax price have no significant effect on the estimated coefficients of alternative fundraising methods.

I have also estimated alternative models that control for the possibility of donating money as a response to multiple fundraising methods. As additional covariates, these models included interaction dummies that control for each possible combination of fundraising methods. However, in these models, the coefficients on interaction dummies were mostly insignificant, which suggests that interaction among alternative fundraising strategies does not play an important role in charitable contributions. These results are available from the author upon request.
I also repeated the exercise using each fundraising method as the base group. Although not reported, the results are comparable to those reported in Table 4; they are available on request.

If some unobserved covariates are correlated with the amount of donation and responsiveness to a certain fundraising method, then matching-adjusted estimates are biased. The empirical analysis focuses on four fundraising methods: personal solicitations, mail solicitations, media ads and telephone solicitations. It is plausible that people who are more likely to give are also more likely to receive personal, mail or telephone solicitations. However, the outcome variable in the empirical analysis is the amount of charitable contributions of those who are already donors. Therefore, a possible selection problem is partially controlled for due to the nature of the outcome variable.

I report the results from the RM with a caliper of 0.005. However, in order to test the robustness of the results to the selection of neighbourhood, I have implemented the same estimator using several calipers between 0.001 and 0.005. The results are comparable to the reported estimates and are available upon request.

Black and Smith (2004) find that the Epanechnikov kernel estimator performs better than the Gaussian kernel independent of the bandwidth selected and that the performance of the kernel estimator is relatively independent of the selection of bandwidth until one gets to very small bandwidths. I have also tried several bandwidths between 0.001 and 0.1. The results are comparable to my original estimate and are available upon request.

The following variables are used as controls, as described in Table Al: Income90, Tax price of giving, and Black, Hispanic, Female, Age, Family size, Married, Employed, Homeowner, Churchgoer, education, community and year dummies. For each fundraising method, I ensure that the propensity score satisfies the balancing property and conduct the standard t-tests for equality of means in the treatment and control groups, both before and after matching. These tests and the first-stage probit estimation results are available upon request.

Although there is no reason to believe that the effectiveness of alternative fundraising methods differs by state, I also include state fixed effects in equation (5) and re-estimate ordered probit models for each fundraising method. The results are similar to those from the original models and are available from the author upon request.
